DOCNAME: VIDACAR S.A. and OPERGRUP S.L. v. SPAIN
TEXT: The applicant companies are NORP commercial companies whose registered offices are in GPE ( GPE ) . They are represented before the ORG by PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as presented by the applicant companies , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant companies operate gaming concerns equipped , in particular , with fruit machines . They are consequently required to pay duty DATE known as “ gaming duty ” – in the form of an annual lump sum on each fruit machine . The amount is reviewed DATE in GPE ’s DATE budget .

In the present case , the amount of duty payable on each fruit machine for DATE was set at MONEY ( ESP ) by LAW of DATE . However , an additional increase for DATE , raising the DATE duty for each fruit machine to ESP CARDINAL , was imposed by section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE on the adoption of urgent budgetary measures .
The first applicant company paid the ORG ESP CARDINAL in duty for DATE , and the second ESP CARDINAL .

The applicant companies , who did not accept the additional increase and had unsuccessfully attempted to obtain its reimbursement by the ORG , brought applications for judicial review in ORG of ORG maintaining , inter alia , that there had been a violation of the principle that increased penalties should not be applied with retrospective effect , a failure to ensure legal certainty and a breach of the principle that rates of duty should be consistent with those imposed on other gaming activities . To that end , they invited the court to refer the issue whether section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL was compatible with Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE of the LAW to ORG before deciding their application for judicial review .

In a judgment of DATE ORG refused to refer the constitutionality issue to ORG and dismissed the application on the merits . As regards its refusal to make a referral , it cited a decision of DATE in which ORG had held that a statute of DATE imposing an additional increase in duty on fruit machines was not unconstitutional ; it observed , too , that ORG had decided that the LAW did not preclude retrospective effect being given to tax legislation .

The applicant company lodged an amparo appeal against that judgment with ORG . It contended that the refusal of ORG to make a constitutionality referral regarding section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL infringed its right to the protection of the courts and to a fair hearing ( LAW ) . It complained , too , that it had been the victim of discriminatory treatment when compared to other firms engaged in the gaming sector ( LAW ) . It also argued that another NORP court , ORG , had decided to refer to ORG the issue of the constitutionality of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL in the context of an application for judicial review lodged by another gaming company . In the light of that referral , ORG decided to adjourn consideration of the applicant company ’s appeal until it had decided the issue that had been referred to it by ORG . In the latter proceedings ORG declared section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL unconstitutional and therefore null and void as its effect was to cause an unforeseeable and insufficiently justified increase in tax liability that amounted to a violation of the principle of legal certainty .
Notwithstanding that decision , ORG , sitting as a full court , decided on DATE , by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL , to dismiss the applicant company ’s amparo appeal .

The complaint regarding the failure to observe the non - discrimination principle was rejected by ORG , inter alia , on the ground that a finding that section CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL was unconstitutional could not be founded on the basis of the principle of equality stated in LAW but on objectively established factors showing inequality contrary to LAW . While any such inequality could be remedied by other constitutional procedures – such as an appeal or a referral of a constitutionality issue – it could not be remedied through an amparo appeal .

As to the complaint under LAW , ORG reiterated that under its settled case - law it was solely for trial courts to decide whether to make a constitutionality referral and their decision was final . Consequently , a refusal to make a referral did not in principle entail a violation of any fundamental right , even if other courts had decided to make a referral regarding the constitutionality of the same provision of PERSON no . CARDINAL . In the instant case , ORG observed that the applicant company had been in a position to put to ORG of Justice all the arguments it considered appropriate in support of its case that the relevant provisions of PERSON no . CARDINAL were unconstitutional and that that court had carried out a reasoned analysis of the merits of those arguments before rejecting them . As regards the argument that ORG itself had in the meantime declared section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL unconstitutional , it held that the fact that a specific provision had been declared unconstitutional could not be used by itself in amparo appeals since the scope of such appeals was restricted by the LAW to certain fundamental rights and freedoms . It added that where a decision on an amparo appeal came after another decision , in proceedings regarding constitutionality , ORG was not always able to refer to the earlier decision in deciding the amparo appeal even where both sets of proceedings concerned the same statutory provision ; that applied especially where , as in the instant case , the decision on the constitutionality issue was based on LAW ( principles of legal certainty and of the rule of law ) , since that provision was not included in the rights and freedoms that were covered by amparo appeals . ORG added that , as no reduction of a sentence or penalty was at stake , a subsequent declaration that a statutory provision was unconstitutional could not have any effect on proceedings that had ended in a final judgment . It concluded by saying that ORG had applied the impuned provision of PERSON no . CARDINAL after finding that it was consistent with the LAW and , accordingly , that there was no point in making a constitutionality referral to ORG .

The applicant company submitted that , unlike other firms in the gaming sector , it had been prevented by that decision from claiming reimbursement of the increases in duty it had paid on its fruit machines pursuant to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL .

In a judgment of DATE ORG refused to refer the constitutionality issue to ORG and dismissed the second applicant company ’s application on the same grounds as those set out in its judgment of CARDINAL DATE in the first applicant company ’s case .

The second applicant company lodged an amparo appeal against that judgment with ORG . It contended that the refusal of ORG to make a referral regarding the constitutionality of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL had infringed its rights to the protection of the courts and to a fair hearing ( LAW ) . It complained , too , that it had been the victim of discriminatory treatment when compared to firms engaged in other areas of the gaming sector ( LAW ) .

In a decision ( auto ) of DATE ORG decided to dismiss the second applicant company ’s appeal and in so doing referred to the grounds set out in its decision of DATE on the first applicant company ’s appeal .

The second applicant company submitted that , unlike other firms in the gaming sector , it had been prevented by that decision from claiming reimbursement of the increases in duty it had paid on its fruit machines pursuant to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL .
The relevant Articles of the DATE LAW provide :

“ The LAW guarantees the rule of law , the application of norms according to rank , their publication , the non - retrospective nature of provisions laying down increased penalties or restricting individual rights , legal certainty , the accountability of public authorities and the prohibition of any arbitrary act on their part . ”

“ NORP nationals shall be equal before the law and may not be discriminated against in any way on account of birth , race , sex , religion , opinion or any other condition or personal or social circumstance . ”

“ CARDINAL . Everyone has the right to effective protection by the judges and courts in the exercise of his rights and his legitimate interests ; in no circumstances may there be any denial of defence rights .

CARDINAL . Likewise , everyone has the right to [ be heard by ] an ordinary judge determined beforehand by law ; everyone has the right to defend himself and to be assisted by a lawyer , to be informed of the charge against him , to have a trial in public without unreasonable delay and attended by all the safeguards , to adduce the evidence relevant to his defence , not to incriminate himself or to admit guilt and to be presumed innocent .

“ Everyone shall contribute towards the financing of public expenditure according to their financial means through a fair tax system based on the principles of equality and graduation and which , under no circumstances , shall incorporate a power to confiscate . ”
The jurisdiction of ORG is defined as follows :
“ The Constitutional Court shall have jurisdiction for the whole of NORP territory and is competent to hear :
( a ) NORP appeals against the alleged unconstitutionality of laws and regulations having the force of law ... ;
( b ) individual appeals for protection ( recurso de amparo ) against infringements of the rights and liberties referred to in LAW , in the circumstances and manner laid down by law ;
( c ) disputes between the ORG and an autonomous community or between different autonomous communities over the scope of their powers .
PERSON appeals lie only in respect of the rights guaranteed under ORG DATE ; the principles of the rule of law and legal certainty guaranteed by LAW are therefore beyond the scope of such appeals .

“ If in the course of proceedings a judicial body considers that a provision which has the status of law and is applicable in the proceedings and upon whose validity its decision depends might be contrary to the LAW , it shall refer the issue to ORG in the circumstances and manner and with the effects – which shall under no circumstances include suspensive effect – to be laid down by law . ”

“ CARDINAL . Judgments of the Constitutional Court shall be published in ORG together with any dissenting opinions . They shall be final with effect from DATE after their publication and no appeal shall lie against them . Judgments declaring a law or a rule having the force of law unconstitutional and all judgments that are not merely in personam shall be binding on everyone .
CARDINAL . Unless stated otherwise in the judgment , parts of the law not declared unconstitutional shall remain in force . ”
LAW of the Institutional Law on ORG is entitled “ Questions of constitutionality referred by judges and courts ” and is worded as follows :

“ CARDINAL . When a judge or court , of his or its own motion or at the request of a party , considers that a provision which has the status of law and is applicable in the proceedings and upon whose validity its decision depends might be contrary to the LAW , he or it shall refer the matter to ORG , in accordance with the provisions of the present PERSON .

CARDINAL . The judge or court concerned shall make the referral only when the case is ready for trial and within the time allowed for giving judgment . It shall identify the laws or provisions having the status of law in issue and the articles of the LAW that are considered to have been violated and shall indicate and explain why the outcome of the proceedings depends on the validity of the provisions concerned . Before taking a final decision on whether to refer an issue to ORG , the judge or court shall first hear any representations the parties and a representative of ORG may wish to make regarding the relevance of the issue within a DATE non - extendable time - limit that shall apply to each of them . The judge shall give his decision within DATE thereafter , no further action being required . No appeal shall lie against that decision . However , the constitutionality issue may be raised again in subsequent proceedings until such time as the judgment shall have become final . ”
“ A judge or court shall refer constitutionality issues to ORG by sending a certified copy of the main case file and any representations made under DATE . ”

“ CARDINAL . On receipt of the case file the Constitutional Court shall follow the procedure laid down in paragraph CARDINAL of this Article . However , it may in a reasoned decision declare the referral inadmissible after hearing representations by the Attorney General alone if the procedural requirements have not been complied with or the referral is manifestly ill - founded .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court shall inform ORG and the ORG ( through their respective speakers ) , the Attorney General and the Government ( through ORG ) of the referral . If it concerns a law or a provision having the status of law adopted by ORG , the legislative and executive authorities shall also be informed . Each of these bodies shall be entitled to appear before ORG and to make representations on the constitutionality issue within a non - extendable DATE time - limit that shall apply to each of them . Once that period has expired , the court shall give judgment within DATE , unless it gives a reasoned decision explaining why it considers a longer period – not exceeding DATE – to be necessary . ”
